title: Tools for Stock Investors: How to Spot Accounting Red Flags
text:
Text size

Looking at accounting minutiae is hard, but sometimes that is what’s required to understand games companies play to dress up their earnings statements.

This isn’t something nefarious or illegal. Generally accepted accounting principles, or GAAP, allow companies, at times, to present numbers that, while accurate, may not provide the clearest picture to investors. The trick is to learn how to recognize issues early, before they become problems for companies—and stock prices—down the road.

A debate over corporate accounting practices has emerged with the allegations brought by forensic accountant Harry Markopolos, who says that General Electric (ticker: GE) has been misrepresenting the health of its long-term care insurance business. GE has rejected his claims as “meritless.” Others have said his analysis was simplistic.

Accounting expert Robert Willens has some advice for investors who want to look deep into financial statements. “Investors should pay attention to the rate at which receivables are growing vis a vis the rate at which sales are growing,” he tells Barron’s. “An imbalance here can signal suspect sales.”

“Of course, an investor should monitor the inventory account. Growing inventories may signal that the company is misjudging the market for its products and that an inventory write-down is imminent.”

That’s excellent advice, but a little specific. It contains, however, exactly what investors need to know to identify potential problems. The keys are (1) be aware of trends and (2) beware of outliers.

Trends

Let’s look at Willens’s inventory example. If inventory as a percentage of sales jumps without explanation, then the trend isn’t the investor’s friend. It warrants further investigation, perhaps an email to investors-relations personnel.

Any financial metric can form the basis of a trend. Sales and earnings growth are critical things to watch, but inventories, cash flows, and asset returns can be even more meaningful when judging the long-term health of a company.

Outliers

If one company spends much less, or much more, than any of its peers, say, on selling, general and administrative costs, the fact the company is an outlier can be a sign of an unsustainable practice.

In 2018, Kraft Heinz (KHC) spent about 11% of sales on SG&A, while other packaged-food companies in the S&P 500 spent closer to 25%. Kraft may have cut expenses too far. The company wrote off $7.3 billion in assets in February, sending shares lower.

Accounting is hard, especially given companies’ ability to manage their reported results. There’s a connection here to why stocks sometimes sell off in an extreme manner after management reports lower earnings, or sales, than Wall Street expects.

If a company can’t meet its own guidance or Wall Street’s estimates, the thinking goes, something really must be wrong.
